docs.lead_paragraph: With a bit of fanfare but limited hard evidence, a Maryland pharmaceutical company has begun marketing a dietary supplement said to improve sperm quality to couples having trouble conceiving. Already, even while cautioning that research is still needed to verify the claims, some fertility specialists have begun recommending to patients that they try the product, Proxeed. In large part, they say, they are doing so because the active ingredients, long used for other purposes, appear to have no side-effects.

headline.main: In Search Of a Way To Bolster The Sperm

docs.abstract: Sigma-Tau Pharmaceuticals introduces Proxeed, dietary supplement it says improves sperm quality, and it is marketing it to couples having trouble conceiving; some fertility specialists are recommending it to patients, while cautioning that claim must still be verified by research; photo (M)
docs.snippet: With a bit of fanfare but limited hard evidence, a Maryland pharmaceutical company has begun marketing a dietary supplement said to improve sperm quality to couples having trouble conceiving.    Already, even while cautioning that research is still...

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers working with mice have developed a vaccine for gonorrhea that is delivered through the nose and reduces vaginal colonization of gonorrhea bacteria. The findings were reported last week in Chicago at a conference of the American Society for Microbiology. An estimated 62 million people suffer from gonorrhea worldwide, according to the World Health Organization. The American Social Health Association, an organization that studies sexually transmitted diseases, estimates that in the United States, 650,000 new cases are reported each year, though experts note that the rate has been declining fairly steadily over the past decade. But the disease is rising among young people and in minority groups.

headline.main: A Gonorrhea Vaccine Is Tested in Mice

docs.abstract: Researchers working with mice develop vaccine for gonorrhea that is delivered through nose and reduces vaginal colonization of gonorrhea bacteria; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: For anyone exercising in hot weather, experts say that even working up a sweat takes practice -- a practice called acclimatization, which means getting the body used to the special demands of the hot weather. Those who rush into workouts in hot weather risk overexerting the body before it is prepared to shed heat efficiently. The consequences could range from having a less rewarding workout to, in the worst cases, triggering an underlying heart problem or fatal heat stroke.

docs.lead_paragraph: Tom tripped over an untied shoelace, fell into a closet that should have been closed and broke his arm when he landed on a shelf. Ruth slipped going up the poorly lighted stairs in her home, hit her head on an upper rung and needed four stitches to close the wound in her scalp.

headline.main: Falls by Elderly, a Perilous Yet Preventable Epidemic

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on falls, a major health hazard for elderly; reviews fall-prevention program of American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Four months ago, Valerie Millerick finally made a decision that she had been putting off for years: She began taking weekly injections of a drug called Avonex, to treat multiple sclerosis. Ms. Millerick, who is 54, had been living with the illness for about two decades, and for most of that time she did not think she was sick enough to need regular treatment.

headline.main: Experts Ask Why So Few Take Drugs for M.S.

docs.abstract: Scientists question why people with multiple sclerosis, an incurable disease, have been so slow to take new drugs--Avonex, Betaseron and Copaxone--that can keep their disease from getting worse; last fall, Multiple Sclerosis Society reported that only 18 percent of people who could benefit from drugs were taking them; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The crowd was growing larger and its mood was turning ugly. People were muttering to each other, picking up magazines and tossing them aside, checking their watches, snarling at the personnel behind the check-in counter. Bad weather at J.F.K.? A train out of service at Penn Station? No, actually, this was the scene a few weeks ago in the waiting room of the medical clinic where I work, where one of the creakiest known systems of human processing, health care in action, had temporarily ground to a halt.

headline.main: Getting Waiting Rooms to Run on Time

docs.abstract: Dr Abigail Zuger Essay on problem of patient flow in doctors' offices, where frayed tempers can result as patients wait endlessly for their appointments; ntoes measures taken to improve efficiency, cost-effectiveness and consumer satisfaction at doctor's office (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The National Weight Control Registry is keeping tabs on more than 2,500 people who have lost weight, and researchers are looking for more volunteers to join the study. Participants must have lost at least 30 pounds and kept it off for at least one year. In the five years since the study began, the researchers have come up with some general findings about people who lose weight and keep it off.

headline.main: A Closer Look at Those Who Stay Slim

docs.abstract: National Weight Control Registry is keeping tabs on more than 2,500 people who have lost weight, and researchers are looking for more volunteers to join study; participants must have lost at least 30 pounds and kept it off for at least one year; there appear to be three common factors in those who maintain weight loss: they eat low-fat diet, they watch their total calorie intake, and they have very high level of physical activity (S)
